chapter: Lens - Cataract Surgery, Complications and IOLs

questions.question: A child has congenital cataract involving the visual axis, which was detected at birth. Whenshould the child be operated up on?

options.C: At 1 year of age, when the globe attains normal size
options.D: At 4 years, when ocular and orbital growth is complete

questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery, Complications and IOLs

questions.question: In which of the following cataract surgeries is a self-sealing sclerocorneal tunnel incisionused?
questions.explanation: The self-sealing sclerocorneal tunnel incision is made in small-incision cataract surgery (SICS).SICS is a type of extracapsular cataract extraction techniques (ECCE). In these techniques,the major portion of the anterior capsule with the epithelium, nucleus, and cortex are removed,leaving behind the intact posterior capsule.Note: Newer cataract surgeries include femtosecond laser-assisted cataract surgery (FLACS),micro-incision cataract surgery (MICS) and Phaconit. FLACS is a microincision cataract surgery ora micro-phacoemulsification where a femtosecond laser is used to make the corneal incisions,perform capsulorhexis and fragment the lens. MICS refers to the phacoemulsification techniquesthat can be performed through a microincision (<2 mm). Phaconit is the term for the bimanualmicro-phacoemulsification done with the needle incision technique through an incision of<1mm.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery, Complications and IOLs

questions.question: In which of the following patients is an intracapsular cataract extraction indicated?
questions.explanation: At present, the only indication of intracapsular cataract extraction (ICCE) is markedly subluxatedand dislocated lens.In ICCE, the entire cataractous lens along with the intact capsule is removed by rupturing thezonules. Therefore, weak and degenerated zonules are a prerequisite for this method. Methods of289lens delivery include cryoextraction (best method), forceps extraction (Arruga forceps), wire vectismethod and Indian Smith method. ICCE is no longer used for cataract treatment due to the largeincision required, inability to implant an IOL and a high rate of complications like vitreous loss,retinal detachment and cystoid macular edema.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery, Complications and IOLs

questions.question: What is the length of the incision used in phacoemulsification?
questions.explanation: The length of the incision in phacoemulsification varies from 1.5 to 2.4 mm. The option closest tothis answer is B, i.e., 2 to 2.5 mm.In phacoemulsification, the nucleus of the lens is emulsified and aspired. This is done by thephacoemulsifier. It acts through a hollow 1-mm titanium needle, which vibrates by at anultrasonic speed of 40000 times a second. The steps of phacoemulsification are given below:Step 1 - Small clear corneal incision•••••.•Step 2 - Continuous curvilinear capsulorhexisStep 3 - Hydro dissectionStep 4 Hydro delineation is done in some cases.-Steps 5 and 6 - Emulsification and aspiration of the nucleusStep 7 - Removal of the cortical lens matter using an irrigation-aspiration techniqueStep 8 Implantation of a foldable lens-Length of the incision in various cataract surgeries:⚫ Phacoemulsification- 1.5-2.4 mm.•• Micro-phacoemulsification- 1-1.5 mm.•• Intracapsular cataract extraction (ICCE)- 12–14 mm.•Extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE)- 8–12 mm.PhacoemulsificationRROMARROW290
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery, Complications and IOLs

questions.question: What is the most common late complication following cataract surgery?
questions.explanation: The most common late complication following cataract surgery is posterior capsule opacification.Posterior capsule opacification, known as after or secondary cataract, is the most common latepostoperative complication. It may be caused by residual opaque lens matter or proliferation ofleft out anterior epithelial cells.Types of after-cataractDense, membranous after-cataractMACOWSoemmering's ringElschnig's pearlsMARROW
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery, Complications and IOLs

questions.question: In a patient undergoing cataract surgery, which of the following is the most importantstrategy in the prevention of postoperative endophthalmitis?

options.B: One week antibiotic therapy prior to surgery

questions.explanation: The most important factor in the prevention of postoperative endophthalmitis is preoperativepreparation with povidone-iodine.Postoperative endophthalmitis is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus epidermidis. Flora ofthe eyelids and conjunctiva are the most frequent source. Other potential sources includecontaminated solutions and instruments, environmental air, and the surgeon and other operatingroom personnel.Prophylaxis for postoperative endophthalmitis includes:• Instillation of 5% povidone-iodine into the conjunctival fornices and leaving this undisturbed forat least 3 minutes prior to surgery. This is the most important factor.•Scrupulous preparation of the surgical site• Treatment of pre-existing infections such as blepharitis• Antibiotic prophylaxis•• Intracameral cefuroxime (1 mg in 0.1 mL) injected into the anterior chamber (AC) at the end ofsurgery.291•⚫ Post-operative subconjunctival injection can achieve bactericidal levels in the AC for at least 1–2hours.• Preoperative topical fluoroquinolone antibiotics are frequently given in regimens from 1 hour to3 days before surgeryPatients present with ocular pain, diminished vision, circumciliary congestion and hypopyon. Thedifferential diagnosis for postoperative endophthalmitis includes retained lens material in the AC,vitreous hemorrhage, postoperative uveitis and toxic reaction to the use of inappropriate orcontaminated irrigating fluid or viscoelastic.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery, Complications and IOLs

questions.question: A patient, 36 hours after cataract surgery, presents with complaints of pain and visualdisturbance. His eye is as shown below. What is the management of this condition?281

options.C: Bandage and padding of the eye

questions.explanation: A post cataract surgery patient presenting within 36 hours of surgery with inflammation,congestion and hypopyon as seen in the image, is suggestive of acute bacterial endophthalmitis.The treatment of acute bacterial endophthalmitis is intravitreal antibiotics.Endophthalmitis is an intraocular inflammation affecting the inner structures of the eyeball.Acute postoperative bacterial endophthalmitis occurs within 1-7 days after cataract surgery andthe most important factor to prevent it is preoperative administration of 5% povidone iodine. Thecardinal features of endophthalmitis are pain, swelling of the lid, and a decrease in vision. Thepatient classically shows inflammation of the eye, corneal edema and a hypopyon due to thepouring of exudates in the vitreous cavity, anterior chamber, and posterior chamber.Once the endophthalmitis sets in it is important to treat all the cases empirically with acombination of antibiotics and steroids from the beginning. The various drugs, routes and surgicalmanagement used to treat endophthalmitis are as follows:• The mainstay of treatment is intravitreal injections of antibiotics.•• First choice: Vancomycin 1 mg in 0.1 mL plus ceftazidime 2.25mg in 0.1ml.Second choice: Vancomycin 1 mg in 0.1 mL plus amikacin 0.4mg in 0.1ml.• If there is no improvement, a repeat intravitreal injection should be given after 48 hours• Topical antibiotics are started immediately and used frequently.•Vancomycin (50mg/ml) or cefazolin (50mg/ml)●Amikacin (20mg/ml) or tobramycin• Systemic antibiotics have a limited role in the treatment but are commonly used in practice.• Steroid therapy includes:• Intravitreal injection of dexamethasone (0.4mg in 0.1ml) which is started along with antibiotics.•Topical dexamethasone (0.1%)•• Oral steroids such as prednisolone are started after 24 hours of intensive antibiotic therapy.•Supportive therapy includes:• Cycloplegics such as atropine 1%292•Anti-glaucoma drugs such as oral acetazolamide or timolol in patients with raised intraocularpressure• Pars plana vitrectomy is done if the patient does not improve with the above therapy in 48-72hours or when the visual acuity is reduced to hand movements near the eyeOther options:Option A: Steroids are given in endophthalmitis to reduce the inflammation of the tissues. Thepreferred route of administration is either by intravitreal injections, topical concentrations or oralroute. Intravenous route (option A) of administration of steroids is not used in endophthalmitis.Option B: Systemic administration (intravenous) of antibiotics have a limited role in the treatmentbut are commonly used in practice as an add on.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery, Complications and IOLs

questions.question: A 62-year-old presented with diminished vision 1 year after cataract surgery. The findings areshown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Diminished vision 1 year after cataract surgery, supported with the image of vacoulated clustersseen behind IOL is suggestive of Elschnig's pearls. It is a type of after cataract.After cataract, or secondary cataract or posterior capsular opacification, is a late postoperativecomplication that follows extracapsular extraction of the lens. It is the most common latepostoperative complication. It may be caused by residual opaque lens matter or proliferation ofleft out anterior epithelial cells. Different types of after cataract include:•Elschnig's pearls: The subcapsular epithelial cells proliferate and develop into vacuolated soapbubble like clusters along the posterior capsule.•Soemmering's ring: A peripheral dense ring is formed behind the iris and is enclosed betweenlayers of the capsule.•⚫ Dense membranous after-cataract: It is formed in the pupillary area impairing the vision.• Thin membranous after-cataract: It is thickened posterior capsule.Types of after-cataractDense, membranous after-cataractMACOWSoemmering's ringElschnig's pearlsMARROW293Treatment of after cataract is by Nd-YAG laser capsulotomy of the posterior capsule, which workson the principle of photodisruption, or surgical posterior capsulotomy.Option B: Irvine-Gass syndrome is cystoid macular edema (CME) that develops in post-cataractsurgery patients. Though it is mostly clinically insignificant, some cases can present with blurringof vision, one to three months after surgery. In CME, on fundoscopy a honeycomb appearanceand on fundus fluorescein angiography(FFA) flower petal pattern can be seen. The below imagedepicts the flower petal pattern seen on FFA.Option C: Post operative endophthalmitis presents as ocular pain, diminished vision andhypopyon within months to years after the surgery. Fungal endophthalmitis can rarely occur withpuff ball exudates in the vitreous cavity.Option D: UGH syndrome is where uveitis, glaucoma and hyphema occurs simultaneously. It isseen commonly with rigid anterior chamber intraocular lens (IOL) implantation.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery, Complications and IOLs

questions.question: What is the treatment of choice for after cataract?
questions.explanation: Nd:YAG laser is the treatment of choice for after cataract.Thin membranous after-cataract, thickened posterior capsule and Elschnig's pearls are treatedwith Nd:YAG laser capsulotomy. Dense membranous after-cataract requires capsulotomy using avitreous cutter. Sommering's ring, if the central posterior capsule is clear, requires no treatment.Other options:Option A: Intra-capsular cataract extraction (ICCE) is currently used for the treatment ofmarkedly subluxated and dislocated lens.Option B: Intravitreal steroids may be used for the treatment of acute endophthalmitis, an earlypostoperative complication of cataract surgery.Option C: Anterior vitrectomy is performed for the treatment of cystoid macular edema withvitreous incarceration. This is a late post-cataract surgery complication.294
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery, Complications and IOLs

questions.question: What is the cause of late-onset endophthalmitis after cataract surgery?
questions.explanation: Late-onset endophthalmitis after cataract surgery is caused by Propionibacterium acnes.Late or delayed-onset endophthalmitis following cataract surgery develops when an organism oflow virulence such as P. acnes, becomes trapped within the capsular bag (saccularendophthalmitis). Organisms can become sequestered within macrophages, protected fromeradication but with continued expression of bacterial antigens. Patients present with symptomsbetween 4 weeks to years (mean 9 months) postoperatively following an uneventful cataractsurgery.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery, Complications and IOLs

questions.question: An elderly male residing in an old-age home is brought to the hospital with senile cataracts inboth eyes. He says he had difficulty in seeing objects for a few years, but never went to theclinic. He is posted for surgery in 3 weeks. Which of the following is a complication is heunlikely to develop in the 3 weeks until his surgery?
questions.explanation: Hypopyon is not a complication of senile cataracts.Hypermature, or senile cataracts, can lead to the following complications.• Phacoanaphylactic uveitis: The lens proteins may leak into the anterior chamber. They may actas an antigen and induce antigen-antibody reaction, leading to phacoanaphylactic uveitis.• Lens-induced glaucoma:• Phacomorphic glaucoma: Most common, seen in intumescent cataract. The lens swells andcauses secondary angle closure glaucoma.• Phacolytic glaucoma: Seen in hypermature cataract. The leaked lens proteins are engulfed bymacrophages, which clog the trabecular meshwork and cause secondary open-angle glaucoma.⚫ Phacotopic glaucoma: Seen in hypermature cataract. The lens may subluxate or dislocate andblock the angle of the anterior chamber..• Subluxation or dislocation of the lens: It may occur due to degeneration of zonules inthe hypermature stage.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery, Complications and IOLs

questions.question: What is the best irrigating fluid for cataract surgery?283

options.B: Ringer lactateBalanced salt solutiond) Balanced salt solution plus glutathioneQuestion 13:How many weeks following surgery are spectacles prescribed?a) 6 weeksb) 10 weeks

questions.explanation: The best irrigating fluid for cataract surgery is balanced salt solution plus glutathione (BSS plus).In the early days of phacoemulsification, the only irrigating solutions available were normalsaline, plasmalyte, and lactated Ringer's solution. Their main adverse effects were endothelial celltoxicity. The buffer in BSS Plus is bicarbonate, which is an improvement over the sodium acetateand citrate buffers in BSS.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery, Complications and IOLs

questions.question: A 72-year-old diabetic who underwent uncomplicated cataract extraction with PCIOL implant15 days back presents with painless, decreased vision in the operated eye. His visual acuity is6/12 and does not improve with a pinhole. On examination, the anterior chamber is deep, andPCIOL is well-centered in the capsular bag. Dilated fundus exam reveals clear media, andoptic nerve with a cup-to-disc ratio of 0.4, a few peripheral microaneurysms, and a dull fovealreflex. The rest of the fundus exam is unremarkable. Which test would be of least benefit?
questions.explanation: In the above case scenario, gonioscopy would be the least helpful.A painless decrease in vision after cataract surgery could be due to:• Posterior capsular opacification (most commonly, after 1-3 months)••Cystoid macular edema (early)Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment (delayed)In the given question, the media is clear (rules out posterior capsular opacification). Also, thereare no symptoms nor signs of retinal detachment (RD), hence it is ruled out. Decreased vision notimproving with a pinhole in the presence of clear media is attributable to macular pathology. Also,there is a dull foveal reflex. The diagnosis in this patient is cystoid macular edema (CME).The incidence of clinical CME is about 1% to 2% following uncomplicated cataract surgeries. Theincidence of angiographic evidence of CME is 10 times greater at around 10% to 20%.Optical coherence tomography (option A) is useful in identifying cystoid macular edema andevaluating the vitreomacular interface. It is also useful in the measurement of retinal thickening,thus allowing the assessment of the therapeutic response. On fluorescein angiography (option B),the classic petaloid leakage in the fovea is seen in the case of CME. Amsler's grid (option D) is amacular function test.Hence, the least useful in this scenario is gonioscopy.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery, Complications and IOLs

questions.question: Two months after undergoing cataract surgery, a 45-year-old man is found to have aftercataract. He is planned for an Nd:YAG laser posterior capsulotomy. What is the principlebehind the use of this laser?
questions.explanation: The principle of the Nd:YAG laser (1064 nm) is photodisruption.Nd:YAG laser capsulotomy is used for treatment of thin membranous after-cataract, posteriorcapsular opacification and Elschnig's pearls. The plasma produced at the laser target expands anddisrupts the tissues, creating an opening. Double frequency Nd:YAG laser is used in posteriorsegment photocoagulation.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery, Complications and IOLs

questions.question: Which of the following complaints in a patient presenting to your OPD would prompt you toperform a Fincham's test?
questions.explanation: Fincham's test is used to distinguish whether the colored halos are due to cataract or glaucoma.Colored halos are rainbow-colored rings seen around lights at nighttime. It may be caused bycataracts, acute congestive glaucoma and mucopurulent conjunctivitis. These conditions lead toprismatic disruption of light.296
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery, Complications and IOLs

questions.question: As part of the pre-operative evaluation of a patient posted for cataract surgery, you are askedto calculate the power of the IOL to be implanted. What investigation do you perform?
questions.explanation: The power of the intraocular lens (IOL) to be implanted after cataract surgery is calculated by abiometer and the procedure is termed as biometry.Biometry consists of keratometry and axial length measurement. The most common method ofdetermining IOL power uses a regression formula called modified Sanders-Retzlaff Kraff (SRK)formula, which is given below:E=A 2.5L 0.9KWhere,•--• E is the emmetropic power designated for the eye• A is a predetermined constant, which is specific for each intraocular lens type•• L is the axial length of the eyeball in millimeter, determined by using the "A" scanultrasonography⚫K is the average corneal curvature, which is determined by keratometry.The image given below shows a biometer.TOMEY
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery, Complications and IOLs

questions.question: In the SRK formula for intraocular lens power calculation 'E=A-2.5L-0.9K', the value of L isestimated using
questions.explanation: In the SRK formula, the value of L is calculated using the A-scan ultrasonographic biometry.The most widely used formula for intraocular lens power calculation is the modifiedSanders-Retzlaff-Kraff (SRK) formula, given by:EA 2.5L 0.9KWhere,--•E: Emmetropic power designated for the eye• A: Predetermine constant which is specific for each intraocular lens type.297••L: Axial length of eyeball in millimeters, determined using the A scan ultrasonography.• K: Average corneal curvature determined by keratometry.Given below is an image of A scan ultrasonography.MProbe/ AntcornealensPostlensRetinaRROMARROWScleraWVOrbital tissues
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery, Complications and IOLs

questions.question: What is a rigid intraocular lens made of?
questions.explanation: Rigid IOLs are made of polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA).Depending on the type of material of manufacturing, 3 types of posterior chamber intraocular lens(PCIOLs) are available:•Rigid IOLs are made entirely from polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA).• Foldable IOLs are made of silicone, hydrogel, acrylic, and Collamer. These are implantedthrough a small incision.• Rollable IOLs are ultra-thin IOLs made of acyrlic or hydrogel. These are implanted through a1-mm incision after micro-incision cataract surgery technique.
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery, Complications and IOLs

questions.question: A patient, on follow-up after cataract surgery, has the lens shown below. What is the type oflens implanted in the patient?

options.B: Modified C loop posterior chamber IOL

questions.explanation: The image depicts Singh and Worst's iris claw lens.This lens is an iris-supported lens, which is fixed with the help of sutures, loops or claws. They areassociated with a high incidence of postoperative complications and are thus only used if posteriorchamber IOLs cannot be implanted.298Intraocular lensesPosterior chamber IOL(modified C loop type)Posterior chamber IOL(four loop type)Anterior chamber 10L(Kelman multiflex)©MARROWSinghand Worst'siris claw lonsNote: Kelman multiflex type of anterior chamber intraocular lens (ACIOL) is the most commonlyused ACIOL. Anterior chamber IOLs lie entirely in front of the iris and are supported in the angleof the anterior chamber. These are associated with a higher incidence of bullous keratopathy.Thus, they are currently used only for correction of aphakia in cases where posterior chamberIOLs cannot be used (eg: rupture of posterior capsule).
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery, Complications and IOLs

questions.question: An 80-year-old man is posted for cataract surgery. The given lens is chosen to be used forimplantation. Identify the lens.286

options.B: Modified C loop posterior chamber IOL
options.C: Singh and Worst's iris claw lens

questions.explanation: The above image depicts a modified C-loop type of posterior chamber intraocular lens (PCIOL).A PCIOL rests entirely behind the iris. They may be supported and fixed by capsular bag fixationof PCIOL (most ideal method), ciliary sulcus fixation or scleral fixation.The PCIOL consists of a central part overlying the optic axis is called the optic and the peripheralarms used for placement and stabilization called the haptics.Intraocular lenses10110Posterior chamber IOLPosterior chamber IOL(modified C loop type)(four loop type)Anterior chamber IOL(Kelman multiflex)©MARROW299Singhand Worst'siris claw lons
questions.chapter_heading: Lens - Cataract Surgery, Complications and IOLs

questions.question: Identify the intraocular lens shown below.
questions.explanation: The given image is of a toric IOL used to correct pre-existing astigmatism. The dotted markingson the optic of the IOL indicate the axis of IOL, and it is aligned to coincide with the steep axis ofthe patient's eye.For every, one degree of misalignment, about 3 percent of the lens cylinder power is lost.300
